Wasfia has spent her whole life helping people's rights. She has worked with many international projects in her home country to teach and train women and girls. However, sometimes these projects end and leave them with nothing. This happened too often in Bangladesh. So, Wasfia decided to combine her two favourite things, mountaineering and human rights, to help change attitudes towards women in her country. She started climbing while working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal. Many people in Bangladesh haven't ever seen a mountain before. Her campaign is working well - people are now paying attention and taking action.

Most people think that poor countries are in a difficult situation: they struggle with extreme poverty, ruled by leaders who don't make decisions fairly, and have limited opportunities for change. However, this isn't entirely accurate. In reality, many positive changes are happening. Over the last 20 years, over 700 million people have gained more money and left poverty behind. This has also led to a decrease in child mortality rates, as well as more girls being able to go to school and having access to clean drinking water.

Managers often give mixed feedback by putting two positive comments after one negative comment. This makes people think that positive feedback is just hiding the problems, rather than helping them improve. So, we need to deliver positive feedback in a way that encourages good work. It's not just about making things better, but also about motivating people to do well.

"We're working together to stop killer robots from being created. These machines are already being used by the military to kill people with some help. But soon, they might be able to make their own decisions and choose who to hurt. This doesn't seem like a good idea and could be very dangerous for us."

Many people around the world are now studying English, which is surprising given that it's spoken in many countries. However, China has the largest number of native speakers of any language. This isn't surprising, as there's no direct connection between the number of native speakers and the number of people who learn the language. Nevertheless, there's a clearer link between the number of learners and the countries where the language is spoken.

Your manager calls you into her office and says she wants to talk about your recent project performance. You're worried about it all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. When you go to her office on Monday morning, she starts by praising you for doing well on the project. This makes me think that the typical feedback process might start like this: say something nice, say what you really mean, say something nice again.

"This fast-paced rock album has songs that make you feel something. Despite its catchy melodies, the album's true strength comes from its stories about the difficult side of life in America. Many of the songs deal with the challenges faced by ordinary people who work hard but don't get rich or famous. For example, the song Glory Days is about people in a small town reflecting on their past when they were young and successful. Another song, Downbound Train, is about a young man whose life is changed when he loses his job. This makes you think that the artist is drawing from his own life and the experiences he had before becoming famous."

Lewis wants to see more marine protected areas in the world. This will help stop the harm caused by fishing, pollution, and littering. He has seen this damage firsthand during his trips. For example, he has swum over coral reefs that are dying because of warmer water. Underwater, there are areas where there is no life and filled with plastic. Pugh thinks that nature can heal if it has space to do so, but we need to act quickly. If we don't look after our oceans, we might face a big problem.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp is known for telling great stories. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. Born on a housing estate in Glasgow, where crime is often high, she learned to be quiet and stay out of trouble. This helped her develop useful skills, which she later used to write her novels. Now, she appears on TV shows like Police Today and at writing events across the UK.

"Do things get harder every day? Can we really make progress?" asks Steven Pinker in his book. He believes people have become better over time. We now live longer, healthier, and happier lives. However, he is concerned that people are focusing too much on their own groups and not trusting others, which could harm important institutions like democracy and international cooperation."

When people are in a desperate situation in old horror movies, they often can't call for help or the police. Now that we have mobile phones, this situation is a bit more realistic. But what do we do to keep the suspense going? We don't have phone coverage, which makes it hard to make a call just when you need to. If you're a hero in a horror movie, you'll probably face this problem at some point. You might lose your phone or run out of battery right when you need to call for help.

Commercial banana farmers in Central America used to grow a popular variety called Big Mike. However, in the 1950s, they faced a major problem with another type of banana called Big Mike's successor, the Cavendish. This banana was easy to transport, had a strong skin, and tasted great. The Cavendish was grown by many companies in South America, including United Fruit, which made a lot of money from selling these bananas. They did this by cloning the shoots from the original plants instead of planting new ones from seeds. This allowed them to grow the bananas quickly and efficiently.

Spiders have a special liquid inside their bodies called venom. This liquid helps them catch their food or protect themselves from predators. Not many spiders can hurt people, but around 25 kinds can. Although spider bites can be painful, they're usually not life-threatening. In Australia, the Sydney funnel-web spider has been safe from killing people since a medicine was created in 1981 to stop its bites from being very dangerous. However, you should still be careful not to touch spiders like tarantulas. If they feel scared, they might try to get rid of you by throwing some hairs at you. These hairs can then stick to your skin or eyes.

"This horror movie plot is very familiar with many horror films from the late 20th century. It begins with a group of teenagers having fun, but it ends with everyone dying, except one girl. At first, she seems harmless and weak, but by the end, she becomes incredibly brave and resourceful. In the end, she often manages to escape danger."

We can learn about our ability to understand complex language by looking at how our brains work compared to others. It's not just about how big our brains are; it's also what else our brains can do and when and why they changed over time. There aren't many physical clues; old tools don't show us what early humans could say. However, we can see changes in the human face and body over time. For example, around 100,000 years ago, people started making different sounds with their mouths, throats, and tongues. These early sounds helped humans communicate better. Before that, scientists couldn't be sure if early humans talked to each other in a similar way.

Girls should focus on arts and humanities, not just maths and physics like boys. This is partly because there aren't many positive female characters in science stories. Cartoons and stories often portray scientists as strange or awkward men. People think scientists are hard to talk to and don't enjoy working with others. However, these are unfair stereotypes shown by the media. They might make girls think science isn't for them. If girls saw more strong female role models in science, they would be more confident and feel connected to science.

The Scallion is published weekly and given away for free in university buildings. It has around 10,000 readers who are mostly students. Students produce and write the newspaper themselves. Many university students appreciate it for its fun, educational value, and job skills. However, printing newspapers is expensive, which makes it difficult for some students to get their hands on one. This problem also leads to a lot of waste, as many copies are thrown away because people can't easily get their copies.

"We have a problem with losing some of our employees every year. About 12% of them leave us each year. This isn't surprising, as it's a common issue in many companies. Our main goal is to find out why some employees are not happy with their jobs and suggest ways to make things better for everyone."

"I think some things the speaker said really stuck with me. I'm worried that being too connected can make us feel lonely. My friends and I have always been able to be independent and know how to spend time together without needing each other's permission. However, people under 20 are different. They're constantly checking their phones and never get to experience the joy of being alone. This can also mean they miss out on learning how to talk to someone face-to-face."

"It's not always a good idea to accept praise with criticism. When both types of feedback work well together, the good things can become less important and be forgotten. We should give feedback just for the sake of giving it, rather than trying to help."
